content: I'm dmg and we're going to be talking about what to include in a basic dungeon
towel Dungeon tile set for the dungeon tile set these things I

are what I like to call my single square wall pieces so this one is a corner so
just a wall on each corner there and then also the single corridors pieces as
well so two walls down the side and I have four of those and then these are
single single wall sides so I have ten of those and then you have what I call
the blank pieces so there's no walls on them at all so this is what I call a
large corner so it's a four by four square with a wall down each side and
these are 2x2 square with a single wall and then these are three by one and with
one wall and the other one on the end is a four by one so these are my Cardle
pieces so the 2 square and 3 Square Cardinal pieces with two walls as you
can see so these are just straight corridors so I've got five two square
ones and six three square ones and these are four square and five squares so the
squares on talked about are the six not centimeter squares have created in video
two these are my corner and t-junction pieces so you've got a standard corner
piece is a three piece so forming the letter L and as you can see basically it

can see it's a corner in every direction so I've created six of those and two

then of course what would be any dungeon without a four-way crossing it so on to
the rooms these are two by two square rooms
and as you can see I have six of them and they are effectively have a doorway
in each corner and I have swapped the doorway in one of them so that's on a
different side I probably should have done an even number of these just when
you're putting the dungeon together nice to have different size of the room so
these are my three by two rooms again here I've changed up where the doors are
so some on the short side some on the long side someone left some of the right
and you can change them up and put them in different locations and these are my
3 by 3 square rooms and again I've just on one of the wall sides I swap it
around a bit I had one in the middle and one on the edge and this is my 4 by 3
room which I have created an entrance on both sides this is just a very it up a
bit so you know with larger rooms it's more likely you're going to have more
entrances and you can either put it on the short side or the long side if you
like you can create one door so here is my 4 by 4 square room and as you can see
I've put in two entrances again but I've changed where they are in relation to
the rest it's important to measure the correct distances as well as you can see
I've also included a slight wall segment into the room just to vary it up a
little bit it does change because of the size of the room it does change the look
of it now this is my largest piece which is a 5 by 5 I've got three entrances two
on the sides here and that one down at the bottom which I've included slightly
longer wall pieces into it just to create some variation these are all my
tile pieces up to 80 of them all stacked so as you can see it's very easy to
store it's just a matter of stacking them all up and then you just put them
into a box but of course be careful with your box you don't want to have taken a
box off someone who really likes their box so those are the sorts of tiles that
you should be creating for a basic dungeon set there's roughly 80 pieces in
that in future videos we talked about more advanced tile sets that you can
create that different levels and you know have water
